entry.title: Appleâ€™s Texas-Sized Problem
entry.summary: Judd Legum, writing at Popular Information: On Friday, CEO Tim Cook answered a question about Appleâ€™s stance on the Texas ban at an all-staff meeting. Cook said that â€œthe company was looking into whether it could aid the legal fight against the new law.â€ Apple has considerable leverage over the abortion debate in Texas and across the countryâ€‰â€”â€‰but it is not related to its ability to pay for lawyers. Appleâ€™s leverage rests in its status as a major employer and driver of economic growth. If Apple believes that its employees should be able to â€œmake their own decisions regarding their reproductive health,â€ it could publicly state that it will not expand its workforce in states that limit abortion rights. That would have a major influence not only in Texas but in numerous states considering following Texasâ€™ lead. Last week, TechCrunch published the text of a company-wide memo posted to an internal Apple message board regarding Texasâ€™s near-outlawing of abortion. It began: A message about womenâ€™s reproductive health care At Apple, we support our employeesâ€™ rights to make their own decisions regarding their reproductive health. Legum is rightâ€‰â€”â€‰itâ€™s untenable for Apple, or any other company, to â€œsupport our employeesâ€™ rights to make their own decisions regarding their reproductive healthâ€ and ask any woman to work for the company in a state with a law like Texasâ€™s. An immediate hiring and construction freeze in Texasâ€‰â€”â€‰explicitly tied to this outrageous law (which makes no exceptions for rape or incest)â€‰â€”â€‰is the only tenable action compatible with Appleâ€™s stated values. David Simon, linking to Legumâ€™s post: If an employer, this is beyond politics. Iâ€™m turning in scripts next month on an HBO non-fiction miniseries based on events in Texas, but I canâ€™t and wonâ€™t ask female cast/crew to forgo civil liberties to film there. What else looks like Dallas/Ft. Worth? Thatâ€™s the answer. You move your business out of Texas. Any company that expands or initiates new operations in Texas implicitly supports Texasâ€™s abortion ban. Â â˜…

entry.title: The Forgotten Craft & Community of Ice Harvesting
entry.summary:
Ice Ball is a short documentary that follows legendary polar explorer Will Steger and the community that heâ€™s built up around harvesting ice from frozen winter lakes near Ely in northern Minnesota. Steger lives off the grid and uses the harvested ice for refrigeration â€” the ice keeps everything cool in the ice house for the whole year, until the next harvest. Best known for his legendary polar explorations, Will Stegerâ€™s life work grew out of a single log cabin he built after moving to the Minnesotan wilderness at age 25. Reliant on sustainable energy and natural commodities, Steger formed a community and culture based on the principle of mutuality. Central to Stegerâ€™s operation is the lost art of cutting ice for refrigeration. This annual harvest formed a tradition spanning fifty years that became known as the â€œIce Ballâ€. While this old world technology inevitably became obsolete, its disappearance parallels a concerning loss of social interdependence in modern society.
Come for the ice harvesting, stay for the wonderful Minnesotan accents. (via colossal) Tags: videoÂ Â Will Steger

entry.title: â€œCaffeine Was an Amazing Aid to the Rise of Capitalismâ€
entry.summary: In this video, Michael Pollan explains how caffeine is woven into the fabric of modern society. Hereâ€™s the short version of how that came to be: People used to drink a lot of alcohol because water was unsafe, so folks were often in a sort of low-grade stupor. When coffee hit Europe, it provided the stimulation, focus, and energy necessary for people to work better and longer. Voila, the Enlightenment and Industrial Revolution. You can read more about caffeine in Pollanâ€™s latest book This Is Your Mind on Plants (excerpt here) or in his 2020 audiobook called Caffeine: How Caffeine Created the Modern World.
